docs.abstract: Bob Dylan cancels shows in Hong Kong and Taiwan after Chinese govenment refuses him permission to play in Shanghai and Beijing (S)
docs.snippet: Bob Dylan canceled a leg of his Asian tour after the Chinese government refused him permission to play scheduled performances in Shanghai and Beijing this month, Agence France-Presse reported.
docs.lead_paragraph: Bob Dylan canceled a leg of his Asian tour after the Chinese government refused him permission to play scheduled performances in Shanghai and Beijing this month, Agence France-Presse reported. Brokers Brothers Herald, Mr. Dylan's Taiwan-based promoter, said the Chinese culture ministry gave Mr. Dylan ''no alternative'' but to cancel subsequent shows in Hong Kong and Taiwan. ''The chance to play in China was the main attraction for him,'' Jeffrey Wu, Brokers' chief of operations, told The South China Morning Post of Hong Kong. ''When that fell through, everything else was called off.'' The ministry did not respond to telephone calls from Agence France-Presse on Sunday, but Mr. Wu said that the Chinese government had become more selective about performances by foreigners after Bjork's 2008 concert in Shanghai, where she shouted ''Tibet, Tibet!'' while performing her song ''Declare Independence.'' Later that year China imposed rules on such concerts, including one that said, ''Those who used to take part in activities that harm our nation's sovereignty are firmly not allowed to perform in China.''

headline.main: U.S. Waiting for China on Iran Issue

docs.snippet: There is wishful thinking in Washington that China will finally agree to economic sanctions against Iran. Don't count on it, an expert says.
docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK -- You can almost feel the waves of wishful thinking emanating from Washington these days that China, after refusing for years, will finally agree to U.N.-approved economic sanctions against Iran for its violations of obligations under the Non-Proliferation Treaty. China so far has only agreed to negotiations about sanctions -- even as President Hu Jintao has said he would come to Washington, and the Obama administration seems ready to postpone formally naming China a currency manipulator -- but that alone is being seen as a favorable sign, amid a general improvement in the bilateral mood.

docs.abstract: Chinese dissident Hu Jia is denied early release from prison despite concern that mass on his liver may be cancer; is serving three-and-a-half year sentence for inciting subversion as Beijing was preparing for 2008 Olympics (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia | China: Dissident Is Denied Early Release From Prison

docs.snippet: Hu Jia, who has been serving a three-and-a-half-year sentence for inciting subversion, was admitted to a Beijing prison medical center where doctors discovered a mass on his liver, his family said.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- One of China's best-known dissidents has been denied early release from prison despite being seriously ill, members of his family said Monday. The dissident, Hu Jia, 36, has been serving a three-and-a-half-year sentence for inciting subversion, a charge levied in April 2008 as Beijing was finalizing preparations for the Olympic Games. He was ill for two weeks before being admitted to a Beijing prison medical center on March 30, where doctors discovered a mass on his liver that might be liver cancer, according to his wife, Zeng Jinyan.

docs.snippet: One of China's best-known writers, Su Tong, worries that the country is growing at such a breakneck speed that it is losing its anchor to the past.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- As dusk gathered over the Shanghai Bund, an elegant, riverfront stretch of pre-Communist-era buildings, the atmosphere sharpened in the Glamour Bar at M on the Bund restaurant. Su Tong, one of China's best-known writers, was entertaining a large crowd at the Shanghai International Literary Festival with tales of his misspent youth in the canal town of Suzhou during the Cultural Revolution. Mr. Su, author of ''Wives and Concubines'' (made into the film ''Raise the Red Lantern''), ''My Life as Emperor'' and, most recently, the Man Asian Literary Prize-winning ''The Boat to Redemption,'' wondered, to general amusement, why Chinese writers seem to run out of steam at a much younger age than Western writers.

docs.abstract: Excerpts of interview with wrestling's Henry Cejudo, gold medalist in 2008 Beijing Olympics; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Henry Cejudo, the youngest gold medalist in U.S. wrestling history, talked about telling his story to a biographer and his plans to wrestle again.
docs.lead_paragraph: At the Beijing Olympics in 2008, Henry Cejudo, then 21, became the youngest gold medalist in United States wrestling history. This completed a most improbable journey, one captured by Cejudo and Bill Plaschke, a columnist for The Los Angeles Times, in a book titled ''American Victory.'' In 223 entertaining pages, Plaschke told Cejudo's story: life on the street and in a junkyard, in fear of immigration officials and his father, a career criminal, fighting for ice cream and survival. Cejudo took a break from his book tour to talk. GREG BISHOP Q.What's the best reaction you received?

docs.snippet: Geography and China's need for raw materials explain its expanding ambition.
docs.lead_paragraph: China's blessed geography is so obvious a point that it tends to get overlooked in discussions of the country's economic dynamism and national assertiveness. Yet it is essential: It means that China will stand at the hub of geopolitics even if the country's path toward global power is not necessarily linear.

headline.main: Music Bridges the Political Divide in China

docs.snippet: When a Taiwan ensemble performed its reconstruction of imperial court music in Beijing, it marked not just a cultural milestone, but a political one as well.
docs.lead_paragraph: DALIN, TAIWAN -- When a Taiwan music ensemble performed its reconstruction of Chinese imperial court music last year in Beijing, it marked not just a cultural milestone, but a political one. The concert provided a rare opportunity to hear ancient sounds salvaged from a nearly vanished musical tradition. The 3,000-year-old genre known as yayue, or ''elegant music,'' faded with the collapse of dynastic rule in 1911, and nearly succumbed to the later Maoist assault on ''feudalistic'' elements of China's past.

docs.abstract: Chinese banks, flush from record profits that were bolstered by a yearlong lending binge, are expected to face a business slowdown as Beijing tries to slow lending to keep the economy from overheating, Reuters reported.

headline.main: Record Profit for Chinese Banks Not Likely to Last

docs.snippet: Chinese banks, flush from record profits that were bolstered by a yearlong lending binge, are expected to face a business slowdown as Beijing tries to slow lending to keep the economy from overheating, Reuters reported.
docs.lead_paragraph: Chinese banks, flush from record profits that were bolstered by a yearlong lending binge, are expected to face a business slowdown as the government tries to slow lending to keep the economy from overheating, Reuters reported.

docs.abstract: Gao Zhisheng, prominent human rights lawyer whose 13-month disappearance at hands of Chinese security agents stirred international outcry until he resurfaced in March, has again vanished; associates say Gao failed to return to Beijing apartment after spending more than week in Urumqi (M)

headline.main: Chinese Lawyer, Thorn in Authority's Side, Vanishes Again After Resurfacing, Friends Say

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HUMAN RIGHTS AND HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS

docs.snippet: The lawyer and advocate Gao Zhisheng last communicated with family members on April 20 as his plane left the Xinjiang region for Beijing.

byline.original: By MICHAEL WINES; Xiyun Yang contributed reporting, and Zhang Jing contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- Gao Zhisheng, a prominent human rights lawyer whose 13-month disappearance at the hands of Chinese security agents stirred an international outcry until he resurfaced in March, has again vanished, his friends said Friday. Associates said Mr. Gao failed to return to a Beijing apartment on April 20 after spending more than a week in Urumqi, the capital of the Xinjiang region in western China, where he had been visiting his father-in-law. Mr. Gao telephoned his father-in-law as his plane left Urumqi, saying he would call upon his arrival in Beijing, they said.

headline.main: Businesses Look for an 'in' With Beijing

docs.snippet: Increasing opportunities come as the country promotes state-owned businesses and limits market-opening moves.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- Every summer since 2000, General Electric has worked with the world's largest Communist party to pick about 25 Chinese executives for the company's leadership program in Crotonville, New York. The training creates potential Chinese allies for G.E. to help ensure its continued expansion in the world's fastest-growing major economy, company officials say. It is part of an emphasis on government relations that has paid off with contracts to supply jet engines and build wind turbines.
